results.title: Family matters
results.creator_credit: Jack Smith and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Facts for Life”.
Explains the transition from life in the womb to life after birth. Shows care of premature babies and stresses the importance of mother-child contact. Discusses mental milestones of the first 18 months and comments on the mother’s feelings of being on duty for 24 hours a day.

results.title: Family matters
results.creator_credit: Jenny Drew and Robert Van der Vvyer
results.brief_description: The twelve months after the first baby arrives can be a crucial time in a couple’s relationship. The twosome becomes a threesome, and much of a couple’s time and energy is directed towards caregiving, with possible misunderstandings and resentments occurring if each partner does not understand how the other is feeling.

results.title: Family living: who cares?
results.brief_description: A discussion-provoking film which poses the problems created within a family when an elderly man moves into the home of his daughter, her husband and their two teenage children. Conflict develops between members of the family when their lifestyles clash with that of the grandfather, resulting in his asking the question, “Who cares?”.

results.title: Family life: a kibbutz
results.creator_credit: Yehnoa Tarmu and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Analyses life in a kibbutz where all property is owned collectively. Reports on the daily life of members, exploring their responsibilities and attitudes.

results.title: Family life & the active child
results.creator_credit: George A. Colburn, Darrel Schwandt, GPN and DLGHS
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
We learn how families bring the wider world home to children, and how they sometimes serve as a place where society’s failings can begin to be reversed. Christmas Day with families in New York and Moscow serve as the background for an overview of issues relating to family structure and dynamics.

results.title: Family history: getting started
results.creator_credit: Geoff Russell and Video Education Australasia
results.brief_description: Searching for clues to their ancestral past has become a popular hobby and pastime for many Australians. Featuring expert input from Frances Brown, (Genealogy and Local History - State Library of Victoria) this program demonstrates how to begin researching your family history. We look at why people seek the information, how they go about it, and the skills needed to complete an accurate family history project.
results.description: Searching for clues to their ancestral past has become a popular hobby and pastime for many Australians. results.title: Family Group
results.creator_credit: Norman Laird, Dept of Film Production for the Dept of Agriculture and Rodney Musch
results.brief_description: A sheep dog eats part of a dead sheep and spreads hydatid infection to a farmer’s family. Stresses need for constant vigilance against hydatids.

results.title: Family follies
results.creator_credit: Peter J Ketchum and Guidance Associates
results.brief_description: Uses a humorous skit with dances, songs, and production numbers in order to highlight the problems which trouble young people: communication with parents, developing responsibility and independence from parents, and learning to cope with competitive attitudes in the family. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Family
results.creator_credit: Wombat Productions, Inc. and Gene Feldman
results.brief_description: Focusing on a typical nuclear family living in semi-rural Connecticut farmland, the role of the family in contemporary society is reviewed here. Members of this and other families give their views on marriage and family life, some upholding traditional views and others expressing discontent with the established system.
